google/gemini-2.5-flash.details: I have attempted to provide the Tokyo-standard pitch accent for each word. For words where multiple accents are common or possible, I have tried to include them in the specified order (H;A;N;O). For nakadaka accents, the drop point is indicated. Some longer words or less common technical terms might have more variability or less definitively established single accents, so I've used my best knowledge for those based on common usage patterns for similar compounds.

google/gemini-2.5-pro.details: The pitch accent for each word was determined based on standard Tokyo Japanese pronunciation rules and common usage. Long compound words, especially technical or medical terms, often tend towards a Heiban (H) pattern (e.g., 筋萎縮性側索硬化症, 運動ニューロン, 萎縮腎). When the first element of a compound is Atamadaka (A), the accent of the whole compound often remains Atamadaka (e.g., 神経 followed by 神経変性疾患). Some words have multiple accepted pronunciations, which have been noted (e.g., 磁気共鳴映像法, 気分転換). For Nakadaka (N) words, the number indicates the mora after which the pitch drops. Odaka (O) words have the accent on the final mora.

google/gemini-3-pro-preview.details:
The pitch accents are determined based on standard Tokyo dialect (kyōtsūgo) rules and dictionaries (like the NHK Japanese Pronunciation Accent Dictionary). 

General observations:
- 'Heiban' (H) is generally the default for long compound medical terms (e.g., words 1, 11, 13, 14, 17, 21), though professional usage sometimes retains accents on constituent parts or places a downstep. I have provided the most standard dictionary forms.
- 2-mora kanji nouns (on'yomi) found here often fall into Atamadaka (A) (e.g., 2, 4, 5, 9, 12) or Heiban (H) (e.g., 6, 8, 15).
- Compound accents typically involve a drop (Nakadaka) calculated by counting moras (e.g., 3, 24, 26, 28, 29).
- For Word 3 (運動ニューロン), the accent is on 'nyu' (5th mora). 
- For Word 19 (最低血圧), standard accentuation places a drop after 'ke' (5th mora), mirroring 'saikō-ketsuatsu', though Heiban is also heard.
- Word 16 (詳らか - tsumabiraka) is traditionally [2] (drop after 'ma').

deepseek/deepseek-chat-v3-0324.details: The following pitch accents are based on the Tokyo-standard (高低アクセント). For nakadaka (N), the number indicates after which mora the pitch drops. If multiple accents are possible, they are listed in square brackets in the order H (heiban), A (atamadaka), N (nakadaka), O (odaka). Some words may have alternative pitch patterns depending on dialect or usage.

openai/gpt-4o.details: In this response, we'll provide the standard Tokyo pitch accent (高低アクセント) for the provided list of Japanese words. The Tokyo-standard pitch accent can be challenging due to regional variations and multiple acceptable pronunciations in different contexts. Nonetheless, here's a best-effort analysis of each word's most common accent.

anthropic/claude-sonnet-4.5.details:
Here are the Tokyo-standard pitch accent patterns for each word:

1. 筋萎縮性側索硬化症(きんいしゅくせいそくさくこうかしょう): This long medical term has the accent drop after the 9th mora: N9
2. 上位(じょうい): Heiban pattern: H
3. 運動ニューロン(うんどうニューロン): Compound with accent on the 1st mora of ニューロン, overall N4
4. 下位(かい): Heiban pattern: H
5. 両者(りょうしゃ): Heiban pattern: H
6. 細胞(さいぼう): Heiban pattern: H
7. 体/たい: Atamadaka pattern: A
8. 散発(さんぱつ): Heiban pattern: H
9. 性(せい): Atamadaka pattern: A
10. 賭け(かけ): Atamadaka pattern: A
11. 進行性(しんこうせい): Accent drops after 4th mora: N4
12. 神経(しんけい): Heiban pattern: H
13. 神経変性疾患(しんけいへんせいしっかん): Compound word, accent drops after 6th mora: N6
14. 磁気共鳴映像法(じききょうめいえいぞうほう): Long compound, accent drops after 7th mora: N7
15. 間質(かんしつ): Heiban pattern: H
16. 詳らか(つまびらか): Heiban pattern: H
17. 乏精子症(ぼうせいししょう): Accent drops after 4th mora: N4
18. 旧遊(きゅうゆう): Heiban pattern: H
19. 最低血圧(さいていけつあつ): Accent drops after 5th mora: N5
20. 母趾(ぼし): Atamadaka pattern: A
21. 萎縮腎(いしゅくじん): Accent drops after 3rd mora: N3
22. 事典(じてん): Heiban pattern: H
23. この世(このよ): Nakadaka with drop after 2nd mora: N2
24. 飼い主(かいぬし): Nakadaka with drop after 3rd mora: N3
25. 雄(おす): Atamadaka pattern: A
26. 気分転換(きぶんてんかん): Accent drops after 5th mora: N5
27. 煮る(にる): Atamadaka pattern: A
28. 八月(はちがつ): Nakadaka with drop after 2nd mora: N2
29. 寝そべる(ねそべる): Nakadaka with drop after 3rd mora: N3
30. 運ぶ(はこぶ): Odaka pattern: O

x-ai/grok-4-fast.details: Based on my knowledge of Tokyo-standard pitch accent (高低アクセント), I have provided best-effort assignments for each word. These are from memory and typical patterns for common words; medical and rare terms are more uncertain and may have standard readings I couldn't fully recall. For most, a single accent is given. No multiples were identified in my recall, but if applicable, the format would use [H;A;N#;O]. Explanations per word: 1. Long compound, likely flat H. 2. Position noun, initial high A. 3. Compound with loanword, mid drop N3. 4. Similar to 2, A. 5. Both, even tone H. 6. Standard N2 (sai-bō drop after 2). 7. Body, initial A. 8. Sporadic, N2. 9. Nature, H. 10. Bet, N2. 11. Progressive, N3. 12. Nerve, standard N2. 13. Compound disease, H. 14. MRI term, loanword H. 15. Interstice, N2. 16. Detailed (rare), H. 17. Medical, guess N3. 18. Old acquaintance, N1. 19. Lowest BP, N4. 20. Big toe, N1. 21. Atrophic kidney, N3. 22. Dictionary, H. 23. This world, N3 (ko-no-yo drop after no). 24. Owner, N3. 25. Male, H. 26. Change of mood, H. 27. Boil (verb), H. 28. August, standard N3. 29. Lie down, H. 30. Carry, N2.

'Nn' indicates nakadaka with drop after the nth mora. Bracketed alternatives are not exhaustively given except where strongly ambiguous.

9. 性(せい) – two‑mora Sino‑Japanese noun; default accent on the first mora. → A
10. 賭け – native noun derived from the verb 賭ける; default accent on the first mora. → A
11. 進行性 – six‑mora Sino‑Japanese compound; standard pattern is heiban. → H
12. 神経 – four‑mora Sino‑Japanese noun; standard pattern is heiban. → H
13. 神経変性疾患 – long medical compound; the whole phrase is pronounced flat. → H
14. 磁気共鳴映像法 – long technical term; standard Tokyo accent is heiban. → H
15. 間質 – four‑mora Sino‑Japanese noun; standard pattern is heiban. → H
16. 詳らか – the na‑adjective くわか (from 詳しい) normally has heiban intonation. → H
17. 乏精子症 – seven‑mora medical term; the usual pattern is heiban. → H
18. 旧遊 – four‑mora Sino‑Japanese compound; standard pattern is heiban. → H
19. 最低血圧 – eight‑mora compound; standard pattern is heiban. → H
20. 母趾 – two‑mora Sino‑Japanese noun; default accent on the first mora. → A
21. 萎縮腎 – four‑mora medical term; standard pattern is heiban. → H
22. 事典 – three‑mora Sino‑Japanese noun; standard pattern is heiban. → H
23. この世 – the phrase consists of the atamadaka demonstrative この plus the noun 世; the whole phrase is atamadaka. → A
24. 飼い主 – four‑mora native compound; the first element 飼い is atamadaka, so the whole word is atamadaka. → A
25. 雄 – two‑mora native noun; the common pattern is heiban. → H

27. 煮る – two‑mora godan verb; default accent on the first mora. → A

openai/gpt-5.details: Tokyo standard (NHK-style) pitch accent labels. H = heiban (no downstep in the word), A = atamadaka (downstep after first mora), Nn = nakadaka with downstep after mora n, O = odaka (downstep after final mora). For long technical compounds and many Sino-Japanese terms, heiban is common. Where I’m unsure or multiple patterns are common, I’ve given best-effort or multiple options (in brackets).

openai/gpt-5-chat.details: 以下の語の東京式アクセントをまとめました。一般的な辞書（NHK日本語発音アクセント新辞典など）の記述や専門語の傾向から推定したもので、一部推測の含まれるものもあります。

openai/gpt-5.1-chat.details: Below are best‑effort Tokyo‑accent classifications. Some terms are rare/technical and may have multiple possible patterns; when so, I list alternatives in the required order.
